fields.physical_description:
Box in the form of an isoceles triangle, with a hinged top and a shield-shaped iron lock plate, the interior lined with an early 17th century paper printed from wooden blocks in black and red, and portions of a calendar dated 1680. 

Box with mitred joints, with double-pegging. The bottom of one wide, and one narrow plank, apparently nailed up, the boards extending about 5mm beyond the sides of the box, and finished with an applied (nailed) ovolo moulding all round. The lid of one wide and one narrow plank with replaced front corner and chamfered edges (with four modern reinforcing blocks on screws), held on two hand-made hinges of x form, apparently applied after the paper pasted to the lid  The lock hand made and apparently early. The lock hasp reapplied over the repair and held by modern screws.

The stand modern (1850-1920) in a late 17th century style , pegged tenon and mortice construction, on three turned legs (sharp, machine turning) on pad feet, joined by rectangular stretchers, the two rear legs cut down their length.

Under the lid, three transverse freizes on the same sheet:
1) a cock, foliage and the lamb of God, and on the right the Feathers of the Prince of Wales, flanked by C.P. for Carolus Princeps (b.1630), between rhymed biblical texts: (above [P]URE/A SHIELD MOST SVRE Pro 30 [Proverbs xxx v.5] and (below) PAINFVLL HAND/SHALL RVLE THE LAND Pro 21

2) A mermaid with a double  comb and convex mirror, flower-spray, and leopard rampant, between goose, spray SAVE VS O LORD/FROM HEATHENS SWORD (Psalm 6:4) and [FR] OM EVILL STRAY/ AND LIVE FOR AYE Psal 37 2

3) Rosette, pelican, rosette, camel, rosette, between [A] VERTVOVS WIFE GIVES HOVSBAND LIFE Eccles 26 and MAN IS LIKE A SCORPION Eccles 22 6

4) At each end, below the above, are layers of lining-paper inscribed....EVILL STRAY; VERVOVS WIFE GIVES [HO]VSBAND LIFE (left); (right) EVILL HAND SHALL and SAVE VS O LORD FROM, and other fragments.

Inside, on the base side of the triangle:
Freizes of sun-mask, pelican, rosette, camel, and rosette, above AN EVILL WOMAN IS LIKE A SCORPION Eccles 8 6

Part of inscription WORD IS over a fleur-de-lys

Freize of fleur-de-lys, cock, vine, Lamb of God , and fleur-de-lys flanked by C and P, below GOD WORD  IS PVRE/ A SHIELD MOST SURE

inside on the right side: THE PAINFVLL HAND/ SHALL RVLE THE LAND Pro 21, and SAVE VS O LORD/ FROM HEATHEN SWORD Psalm 6 4 above portions  of a freize.

Inside the left side:
Part of the freize above FROM EVILL STRAY

Freize of sunburst, pelican, rosette, camel, rosette above AN EVILL WOMAN IS LIKE A SCORPION Eccles 

On the base of the inside is lined in two or more layers with sheets from calendars one apparently for 1680
fields.bibliography:
Box, triangular, on stand. The box has a hinged top and a shield-shaped iron lock-plate, the interior being lined with an early 17th century paper printed from wooden blocks, and portions of a calendar dated 1680. The stand is modern. English. Early 17th century. From catalogue H. 2 ft. 5 ¾ in., W. 2 ft. 6 ½ in., D. 1 ft. 3 ¼ in. (H. 75.6 cm, W. 77.5 cm, D. 38.7 cm) Croft Lyons Bequest
From: H. Clifford Smith, Catalogue of English Furniture & Woodwork 
(London 1930), 587.
OMAN, Charles and Jean Hamilton: Wallpapers. A History and Illustrated Catalogue of the Collectiron of the Victoria & Albert Museum. (London, 1982), no. 7
fields.history_note:
On loan to Manor House Museum, Bury St Edmunds, returned  December 2006.

On boxes see Victor Chinnery, Oak Furniture. The British Tradtion (Woodbridge, 1979), pp. 364-7b and fig. 3:379 for another triangular box dated 1673.

Triangular box bequeathed by Colonel Croft Lyons (per Mill Stephenson Esq), 8 Neville Street, Onslow Gardens, London SW7.

Notes from R.P. 55/2152 (not reviewed) (also 26/6268 reviewed)

31/7/26 Objects submitted as a Bequest
lists among 7 items "1 Table, triangular, oak, with hinged top   W.51 1926"

Col. Croft-Lyons bequeathed all objects and furniture on loan to the V & A belonging to him and offered the Board of Education the choice of 10 additional items to be selected from his possessions.  

Mr Watts and Mr Rackman of the V & A selected 10 items on 23 July 1926
The triangular "table" is included on a typed list of the objects selected as 
"7.  Triangular oak table with hinged top, the inside covered with contemporary printed and coloured lining paper, 17th century".  The condition of some of the other objects is noted in pencil on the list but there is no such notation next to this table.

Another list in pencil
Notes "7 Triangular oak table  Chas II)

30/7/26 another typed list
assigns the value of £5 to the table (same on typed letter 4/8/26 from Eric Maclagan)

6/8/26 Minute paper Oliver Brackett
supporting the acceptance, refers to the mahogany furniture and the heraldic panel but makes no mention of the oak table.

1937 & 1938 Internal V & A Memoranda 
relates to the legality of loaning the Croft-Lyon bequest items and notes the inclusion of W51-1926 among those in circulation (Belows Hall?)
